If your favourite part of MMOs is doing dungeons with a party of 4, but you're disappointed by how simple and easy the dungeons are in FFXIV, or don't want to keep up with the baggage of playing retail WOW, then Fellowship is exactly what you're looking for.

Fellowship is a nearly 1:1 recreation of the "Mythic Plus" Dungeon system from World of Warcraft; with none of the massive open world or long levelling requirements. Controls, movement, class mechanics, and even aesthetics will be instantly recognisable to any veteran of WOW from the past 10 years, but there's no long levelling process to get into the good part; you can jump straight into a dungeon with well-scaled difficulty, diverse monster types, and engaging bosses alongside 3 of your friends only minutes after installing the game.

The downsides; Dungeons are the focus of the game, and it doesn't have room for much else. There's no open world here, no deep character customization or personalization, and not much room for roleplay. You play a stock Hero setup; a personality, visual, and set of abilities in the same vein as a character from Overwatch or DOTA, only that you're picking between WOW style MMO holy trinity classes.

Second; the solo queue is... hit or miss. Make no mistake; this game is best played with friends. Even duo queues aren't so bad, but if you plan to go at this alone, you'll be subject to both the best and worst that party finder has to offer- and usually the worst. It's not totally intolerable, but it's not great, and as of Early Access in October 2025, the game is missing some important social tools to assist with this.

Still, I think what's on offer is well worth the asking; the second my group got into the flow of clearing dungeons together like the glory days of WOW, we felt right at home, and you might too. Give it a shot!

Let's assume you're familiar with WoW (or a generic MMORPG) and its Mythic Plus (infinitely scaling dungeons) feature. Here's how Fellowship does it better.

[h3]There is no raiding[/h3]
You are not at a disadvantage in dungeons for not committing to play with a structured raiding guild. There might be raids coming, but as I understand the devs are actively opposed to this problem (that Blizzard perpetuates with every WoW season), so I expect these raids to not be mandatory for your dungeon success.

Also, there is no questing or leveling or even an open world. Just dungeons and a hub of services.

[h3]There is no trading[/h3]
You're not paying your local goblins on a regular basis for crafts or consumables. You're not enduring shady loot sales. Players can't trade each other anything or even pass on loot for each other.

[h3]Goons return to our dungeons[/h3]
There are monsters that do nothing but slap the tank. This means you can have fun, large pulls without worrying about how you're going to deal with every monster having three different abilities that you need to account for. Some mobs do things, but some are really just lovely AoE fodder.

[h3]Other delights:[/h3]
* Fear my wrath: When you use a defensive or your ultimate ability, there is a voice line everyone in your party hears. I always feel sorry for the boss when I hear Rime use Wrath of Winter.
* The right amount of lore: The game doesn't really have a coherent story; it leaves a lot to the player's imagination. But the dungeons and flavor texts certainly fill in a lot of blanks without being overbearing. They give you enough to build your own idea, without trying to overcompensate based on being your only sources of lore.
* Trinket design: Every trinket has some stats and a utility usage (resurrection, dispel, move speed, etc). You choose based on the tricks you need for the dungeon, not what you simmed to be the best.

And lastly, someone (or multiple someones) deserves praise for the fact that despite Fellowship early access being a huge success, it's not tainted by overloaded servers. There was foresight here.

Fellowship Review: The Perfect "Casual" Mythic+ Experience (Almost)

If you love the challenge of World of Warcraft's Mythic+ dungeons but don't have the time to commit to a full-blown MMO grind, Fellowship is exactly what you have been waiting for. It effectively distills the best part of dungeon crawlers into a jump-in, jump-out experience that respects your time.

Why It Works for Busy Gamers

For someone like me who doesn't have endless hours to sink into dailies and raids, this game is a breath of fresh air. You get that high-level dungeon crawling "fix" without the massive time investment.

The developers are clearly listening to the community and putting in the work:

Class Balancing: The constant tweaks show they care about keeping the meta healthy.

New Heroes: The roster is expanding nicely, giving us fresh ways to play.

Events: The Haunting of Stronghold Halloween event cool enough for some new skins and mounts.
The One Downside: The Timer

However, there is one mechanic that holds the game back from perfection: The Dungeon Timer.

Just like in WoW Mythic+, the timer forces a "rush culture." Instead of enjoying the dungeon and playing strategically, people just sprint through packs.

It encourages skipping content rather than fighting it.

One small mistake can ruin the timer, making the whole run feel wasted.

It creates unnecessary stress in what should be a fun challenge.

Feedback: Difficulty > Speed

I would much rather see the difficulty come from complex boss mechanics and harder trash mobs than an arbitrary clock.

Let us wipe 100 times on a boss while we learn the strategy.

Let us figure out a puzzle or a tough phase.

That feels rewarding.

Beating a timer just feels like we ran fast enough. Beating a boss that crushed us 10 times feels like a victory.

Verdict

Fellowship is doing amazing work. If the devs can offer a mode that focuses on difficulty over speed, this would easily be the best dungeon crawler on the market.

Current Score: 8/10 (Would be a 10/10 without the timer!)

As pretty much every MMORPG player has already said, Fellowship is basically "Mythic+: The Game." However, if you haven't played World of Warcraft (WoW) before then this won't mean much, so let me try to summarise what Fellowship is.

[h3] Core Gameplay [/h3]

You choose a hero that performs one of three roles: Tank, Damage Dealer, or Healer. Heroes are tied to a particular role. For example, you can't play Sylvie as a Damage Dealer. This is very different to WoW, where you would choose a class rather than a hero, and a class could be built to perform any role. Currently, there are only two Tanks, two Healers, and about half a dozen Damage Dealers. Each hero has their own playstyle and set of abilities, and different heros within the same role can be quite different to play (at least in my experience mostly playing the two Healer heroes). I think the heroes are done well, and I think it is even a strength that heroes are tied to specific roles since it makes for much more streamlined "skill trees."

[h3] [strike] Skill [/strike] Talent Trees [/h3]

Heroes don't have traditional skill trees in which you can unlock abilities. Instead, heroes have a set number of skills that you unlock by completing a certain number of dungeons. To add build diversity, heroes instead a "Talent" tree. Talent Points are unlocked by completing dungeones and beating increasingly difficult dungeons. Talent Points can be spent to buy passive buffs (such as increased Block Chance) or add special effects to your skills (e.g., casting Skill X has a chance to buff your next cast of Skill Y in some way).

[h3] What Do You Do? [/h3]

Unlike WoW, Fellowship does not have an open world. Instead, you spawn in a central hub. In this hub there are a number of vendors you can speak to to buy and modify equipment, and you queue for dungeons by interacting with the War Table. I won't go into the equipment since it's pretty much what you'd expect from a game like this, and I'll only briefly discuss dungeons. Dungeons require a four-player group: one Tank, two Damage Dealers, and one Healer. While it's possible to beat a dungeon with only a single Damage Dealer, as far as I know there is no way to enter a dungeon without being in a four-player group. Dungeons reward you with gear, currency, and a "Dungeon Score." To get the highest Dungeon Score, you have to beat the dungeon as quickly as possible. However, you cannot rush to the final boss since dungeons require killing a certain number of enemies to be completed. Thankfully, you won't fail a dungeon if you don't beat it in the alloted time so you never have to worry about wasting your time. I think the dungeons are done very well.

[h3] The Usual Problems [/h3]

Unfortunately, queueing for dungeons has all the problems you'd expect. If you're playing solo as one of the Damage Dealer heroes, you might be waiting a while. If you're a Tank or Healer, you'll probably find groups quite quickly. If you're unlucky enough to get put into a group with a toxic Tank or Healer, they might ragequit and render the dungeon impossible to beat. While I don't blame the game itself for these problems, I would like to see penalties for quitting dungeons early to deter this kind of behaviour (excluding quickplay, obviously). It's such a frustrating waste of time to queue for a dungeon only to have the Tank or Healer leave you up $h!t's creek without a paddle.

[h3] Combat [/h3]

Once you're in a dungeon, combat is very similar to WoW. This can be a bit of a learning curve for players that never played WoW, especially those playing ranged heroes. "Tab Targeting" is your friend. If you're a healer, you can cast heals on an ally by hovering your mouse of the player's name in the group menu just above your ability bars. By doing this, you can keep targeting enemies while healing your allies instead of constantly changing targets. Tanks and Damage Dealers also have "Interrupt" abilities that can cancel enemy spell casting. This requires a bit of coordination within your group since interrupts have a moderate cooldown. Other than that, combat can be boiled down to: Tank distracts and soaks up damage, Damage Dealers deal damage, and Healers, well, heal. Again, nothing revolutionary, but a tried and tested system that will be familiar to WoW players.

[h3] Another Unreal Engine 5 Game [/h3]

Finally, one last thing I'd like to touch on is Fellowship's choice of engine: Unreal Engine 5 (UE5). I hate UE5. Upon loading the game, you'll see high CPU utilisation during the hero selection screen as shaders are compiled in the background. Trying to choose a hero while this is happening results in a timeout, so you effectively can't play the game until this has happened, but you have no idea how close it is to finishing or roughly how long it will take. Mercifully, the game doesn't run like garbage once the shaders have compiled, though performance is certainly below what I'd expect given how limited the game's scope is. Fellowship is very GPU hungry but I'm not too sure why. Sure, the game looks pretty good, but I don't think the visuals justify the performance. That said, I'm more forgiving of smaller studios using proprietary engines, so I won't complain too much. It's perfectly playable.

[h3] TL;DR/Summary [/h3]

Fellowship is a game about beating progressively difficult dungeons. That's it. It respects your time, and if you have a group to play with the experience can be fantastic. There isn't much "new" here, but it does what it does well. Really well. I expect this game will only get better with time, and right now I'd say it's worth it's asking price. Give it a go. You'll know whether or not it's something you want to play within the first two hours, so you can always refund it if it's not your cup of tea.

First off, I want to say that I REALLY like this game, and I absolutely want to give it a positive review. I think it has a few issues that I hope the devs buff out, and I think that they will! If you have experience in this genre and know how to be patient, are interested in learning mechanics and characters, and have the mentality to not let bad groups bother you, then there is ALOT to enjoy about this game. That being said there is one issue with the game has that has absolutely killed it for me and after encountering it I have not touched the game since; and if remedied I will happily roll my review to a recommend.

Fellowship as I saw it before release, and through the beta tests I participated in seemed to be marketed as a more solo player friendly, time respecting, and more focused alternative to the m+ system in WoW. Easy to pick up and play with or without your friends for just about as long or short as you wanted. The characters weren't bloated by dozens of spells and talents intended to fulfil purposes across several different styles of play, there wasn't 20 years of systems to familiarize yourself with, but still with enough depth to make learning and optimization fulfilling. And there is a lot of optimization in the end game! There are empowered sockets, legendaries, gem bonuses, set bonuses, weapon talent trees, all kinds of stuff. As someone who worked their way through paragon and into the final tier of gear I was looking forward to interacting with all of these systems and make my push towards the cool cosmetic rewards tied to the newly unlocked Eternal queue.

But there is a problem with that. In fact it's such a large problem that it caused me to write this review. Fellowship, the solo friendly, time respecting alternative to m+ in WoW, aided by it's "click a button and you're in a group playing no questions asked", for reasons inexplicable to me, decided to ditch this model in their infinitely scaling endgame mode.

So what is the alternative? It's fine, I've played WoW, I've spent plenty of time in LFG before, and besides, I main a healer, so I should get groups fine? I mean sure, it sucks for DPS players playing non-meta characters since they're just going to be denied from every group, but whatever I guess. Oh wait, whats that? There is no LFG system in the game? Okay well maybe I join a guild then and find people to play with, a Fellowship. Oh, there Isnt one of those either? Okay will this guy in my lobby has some eternal gear, maybe he'll be interested in playing with me? Ah, I can't whisper him, that Isnt in the game either...

So what is my option? Of course it's a clusterfuck discord server moving a hundred miles a minute. God what a fucking mess. You have to just sit in game for 30+ minutes either hoping you can snatch a tank up or hoping you get invited to do one run and disband. Essentially the same fucking experience of adept through paragon but with a extra steps. Baffling decision to me for what I could only imagine is to protect the egos of people coming into the game with their competitive m+ statics.

I've waxxed poetic here but my main point is that I am done with Fellowship because I assumed I was 2/3rds of the way through progression but if I have to piss around in a discord server to do the same shit I was already doing with the click of a button I'm honestly just not going to bother. I'm sure some of the people reading this will find that a petty reason for this rant, or tell me to "just make friends" in the game with no tools to do so, and a game premise that suggested it was unnecessary; And it is fine if you do, but this is where I've decided I'm drawing the line. Ironically it drove me back to just doing m+ in wow because they have a better system for playing the game. Which is a hilarious prospect to me all things considered.

Anyways, if you are experienced in the genre there is a lot to like here for about 60-100 hours, which is really not bad for the entry price. And if you're new to the genre I think it's a lot better entry point than WoW. I think the game is good, I think the devs care about it being good (mostly, unfortunately they seem to also care too much about what Twitch streamers think makes a game like this good), and I've supported it for a while, and I want to leave a good review, but it seems like eternal queue is not a priority for the devs at the moment for some reason, as I have seen no concrete confirmation to a timeframe for its release, and I feel this is the only way I have to make my voice heard. Once it is added I will gladly delete this review.

The game presents well at first glance.
You run dungeons, there’s no leveling, and the onboarding is easy — especially if you already have a group. My team pushed to Eternal 30, earned the 0.1% platinum trims, collected all the Halloween skins, and geared multiple alts just below our mains.

But I can’t recommend this game for high-end M+ players in its current state.

Lack of Long-Term Goals

There’s only a single 10k achievement for a mount, and an 8.5k cap for alts. To put that in perspective: it’s easier than hitting ~3k in WoW M+. A premade group could reach that in roughly two weeks — yet seasons are clearly intended to last far longer. There’s no real “carrot” for the top 5% of players. Once you finish the initial push, the game becomes pure grind with no meaningful progression goal beyond repetition.

Time-Respect Claims Don’t Match Reality

The developers marketed Fellowship as a game that respects your time. Outside of skipping traditional leveling, this simply isn’t true.

Queue Times:
Because difficulty brackets aren’t condensed and the playerbase is small, many queues are dead — especially for DPS. I’ve personally seen queue times stretch beyond an hour.

Eternal Grind:
Once you enter Eternal, the time-respect goes out the window:

You must farm the correct weapon type.
Then you must farm or reroll traits to get the right capstone ability.
Then you sacrifice sets to chase random gem slots and 92 total gems that drop extremely slowly.
Then you need those gem slots with specific stats and empowered gem slots (+35% power).

Meanwhile you’re told the game is “about pushing and beating dungeons,” yet you spend 50–60 hours in Heart of Tuzari alone.

After that, more time in Sailor’s Abyss 10 or 20.
Then you slog through specific cursed dungeons hoping for a BiS drop with empowered stats.

It’s a massive treadmill disguised as endgame progression.

Progression Loops Are Just Leveling With Extra Steps

The game tries to frame Contender → Adept → Challenger → Paragon as something different from leveling, but functionally it’s the same:

7 dungeon levels with ilvl requirement. Clear a capstone  → earn skill points
7 dungeon levels with ilvl requirement. Clear a capstone → earn skill points
7 dungeon levels with ilvl requirement. Clear a capstone → earn skill points
Reach Eternal → earn skill points and a random legendary (No legendary bad luck protection) that may or may not be your BiS

This is leveling — just spread across differently named brackets.

Eternal Mode Is Oddly Structured

Eternal is basically a hunt for the easiest curse combinations so you can skip bad affixes and bad dungeons entirely. Before Eternal even starts to feel good, you’re stuck farming either:

The Paragon capstone dungeon, or Heart of Tuzari Eternal 2
…over and over. My group has probably run that specific dungeon close to 300 times by now.

Overall

I’m disappointed with where the game currently stands. Not everyone needs a carrot to keep pushing endless dungeons, but many of us do — especially players coming from high-end M+. The game was marketed as respecting your time more than “that other game” (WoW), yet it ended up building the same systems with different names and even heavier RNG-based grind.

There’s a solid foundation here, and the dungeon gameplay itself is fun. But unless Fellowship adds meaningful long-term rewards or progression for top-tier players, it risks losing exactly the audience it was designed to attract.

Let it be known, I love this game. Truly. And despite the review, I’ll still play it, as it’s a great relief of stress for me.

I love games where I can relax, turn my brain off after a long day of work, and just unwind. That’s usually what I’d do as a tank, either Helena or Meiko. That was my fun. It’s why I enjoy games like Guild Wars 2, I don’t have to regrind everything just to stay relevant.

It’s the perfect “WoW dungeons only” experience. It brings that mythic atmosphere into it, while also being a charming, amazing, and well-optimized game in my opinion. However, I have to mention the one thing that really holds it back, full seasonal resets.

My biggest gripe is the fact that its Seasonal Progression isn’t just a small wipe, it’s a full wipe. Instead of your old gear being downscaled for a new season, you start completely from level 1 again. Many people compare it to PoE, but it’s better to reference WoW’s Mythic+ seasons, since that’s what this game is really trying to emulate, a dungeon grinder / Time-trial.

You’ll have to relearn all your skills, even ones that felt like baseline for your character. Hopefully the skills stay on the hotbar, having to rebind everything each season would get frustrating fast. But honestly, knowing there’s a full reset coming kills my motivation to grind if everything’s just going to be deleted.

For example, I was working on my “cool, chill tank girl” Helena build. She’s the mitigation tank, and I wanted two specific items: the Saltwash Elixir, a trinket that gives you a fair heal on a cooldown, and the Grimoire, which lets you bring back a player from the dead, basically letting me play a more relaxed, paladin-like style. But with a reset every season, it’s hard to justify putting in that time. What’s the point in chasing gear if it’s all going to be trashed and reset next season?

“Ooh, there’s going to be new modifiers for the dungeons!” — sure, but that usually just means shifting a few around and adding a couple of new ones.
“Ooh, there’s going to be two new characters!” — it’s a tank and a healer. (People were even upset both tanks were female, so maybe this next one’s a guy?)
“You should strive to be better and no-life the game!” — some of us literally have jobs and just want to relax, run a few dungeons with friends, and have a ‘fellowship.’

I work for my money like anyone else. The difference is, I want to keep what I earn, or at least have the option to opt out. Maybe opting in to seasonal resets could reward cosmetics or mounts. That way, both sides would be happy: let the competitive players race the new ladders, while the rest of us relax and enjoy the game the devs built up.

I want to gear everyone, explore fun little non-meta builds, and just have fun. But it seems like the devs have the full reset idea set in stone. I’ll keep playing because I love what’s here, but I truly hope the devs reconsider. Fellowship could be something special for both competitive and casual players alike. Should the devs ever change their minds about it, I’ll gladly change this review to positive.
